Score following is the process of automatically listening to a live music performance and tracking the position in the score. It is an active area of research and stands at the intersection of artificial intelligence, pattern recognition, signal processing, and musicology. Score following was first introduced in 1984 independently by Barry Vercoe and Roger Dannenberg.
Artistically, it is one of the main components for live electronic music of many composers such as
Pierre Boulez and
Philippe Manoury
among others and is currently an active line of research in different communities such as
IRCAM
in Paris. The latest version of IRCAM's score following, developed by the Real-Time Applications Group and put in performance in February 2005, make use of an intelligent system that learns the characteristics of a performance out of the rehearsal recording for better accompanyment in the live situation.
Other score following authors include Chris Raphael, Roger Dannenberg, Barry Vercoe and
Miller Puckette
, and Frank Weinstock ( U.S. Patent 5,952,597 ; U.S. Patent 6,107,559 ; U.S. Patent 6,166,314 ).
For the first time, in October 2006, there is going to be a Score Following evaluation during the second Music Information Retrieval Evaluation eXchange (MIREX). It is expected that most systems participate and compete in live musical situations and the results be announced in public domain.
